metadata.title: Python Functions in Slow Motion. Strategies and practice problems for… | by Mia Iseman | Towards Data Science
metadata.description: There is a widely held belief that we are either right-brained (imaginative free spirits) or left-brained logical robots). Turns out, it’s all a myth. We don’t even have brains! At least that’s how…

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: Adopting a positive mindset is important for any task
found a similar question on Stack Overflow

all_paragraphs: There is a widely held belief that we are either right-brained (imaginative free spirits) or left-brained logical robots). Turns out, it’s all a myth. We don’t even have brains!

At least that’s how it feels as I begin to study data science. Sometimes, I can’t process all the information my eyes and ears are trying desperately to take in. Other times, I feel like I’m on autopilot and the built-in formulas and libraries are doing all the work. You may think the latter is a desirable state, but I’d much rather know what’s going on “under the hood.”

Writing functions is a sweet spot where — call it middle-brain? — creativity overlaps with problem-solving in the most obvious way: you create something that solves a problem. Within the context of the larger project you’re working on, it’s nice to have this small success — to see that the stuff you put under the hood worked.
Problem is, I’m not very confident when writing functions… yet. I’m going to share with you what I’ve learned about writing them along my journey to becoming more confident.

I assume that if you’re still reading, you have at least tried to write a few functions. I skip some major definitions and requirements (plenty of tutorials and documentation cover them already) and instead focus on tangible things we beginners can do to help ourselves write python functions in the actual moment that we need to write them. Note: A summary of the process I outline within this article can be found at the end, if you’re a list person!

When I need to write a function, I immediately get nervous. Will I be able to do it? On the first try? Fast enough? It’s harder for me to be creative or logical when I’m distracting myself with pointless questions like that first.

Even in technical interviews, the function output and how long it took you is not what’s important — what’s being measured is your resolve, resourcefulness, and approach to problem solving. Instead of getting scared, we ought to write functions as if we’re doing a jigsaw puzzle.

Some people place all the edge pieces first, some group all the similarly colored pieces together, some people look at the box constantly, some prefer to work with a group and others alone, and most move at their own pace and enjoy the process of putting it together. I’ve never been nervous to put a puzzle together. In fact, it’s relaxing.
Adopting a positive mindset is important for any task, and that’s just as true for writing Python functions!

Perhaps you are also just beginning to learn Python, like me. As a beginner, I often rush myself unnecessarily. I’m not sure why! If someone is looking over my shoulder, they are more than likely rooting for me to write the function successfully. I know very few interviewers who are rooting against their candidates, and in those cases you probably don’t want to work with those people anyway. If you’re pair programming, your peer hopes you are successful, and they don’t have a time limit for you. The need for speed is all in our heads!

The idea of “slowing down to speed up” is incredibly value in several applications, but especially when learning something new. If we take our time at the beginning, spending a couple extra hours to understand a topic, then we may save ourselves a couple weeks of work down the line. Adhering to this philosophy means we can’t gloss over solutions for functions that we failed to write ourselves. We have to take the time to understand those too.

Obviously we don’t have all the time in the world. Balance taking your time with the old “work smarter not harder” adage, and know when you’ve reached the point of diminishing returns, which is almost certainly not before trying several times on your own. If you don’t have someone in person to ask for help, Stack Overflow is amazing.
If we spend a couple extra hours to understand a topic, then we may save ourselves a couple weeks of work down the line.
Okay, now we’re going to enjoy tackling this problem, and we don’t need to rush at all. Let’s do it.
Write a function that finds the maximum of three numbers.
Before we start giving the computer commands, let’s focus on how a human would solve the problem. Once we think about our own thinking, we’ll translate that to Python.

For this problem, working backwards is helpful for me. (You may think of a different way off the top of your head.) If we’re looking for the maximum, then our output will be one of the inputs. How will I know which input to return?

If I did this problem with three numbers, like 1,2, and 3, how would I find the maximum? Look at the first two numbers and see which is greater. Then compare that greater number to the third number. Return whatever the greatest number of those two is.

Writing down what you want the code to do in the comments is a great interim step for keeping track of your ideas somewhere outside of your own brain. The old idea that if you can explain something then you fully understand it holds true here — if we can explain through comments what the the function is supposed to do, that’s half the battle.
Tip: To comment out multiple lines at once, press command / . Try it!
Remembering that there is no time limit, now I’ll try to translate to python.

Admittedly, this is sometimes the hardest part as a beginner. We don’t know what is possible, and have to often look up the documentation, examples, or look at a cheatsheet. However, for me, making mistakes is one of the best ways to learn new information. It’s like a good kind of trauma: Whenever I’m in a similar situation, I’m more likely to be “triggered” and reminded what will happen if I make the same mistake again.
For our max_of_three example, a comparison makes me think that I should use an if statement concerning the values of the first two numbers:

Now, I imagine running the function. I’ll test the function when I’m more confident in my solution, but for now I’m just getting started and simply imagine inputting values. I realize that I don’t deal with the third number c at all. So, according to my comments, before I return anything, I need to compare my a and b to the third number c. So, it seems like I should compare the greatest number to c in each case, since I’m not ordering the numbers and instead just returning the greatest one. Notice this is different than my original comments, but that’s okay! I’ll give it a try:

I think my logic is sound. At this point, I might move on to the elif statement, but I just realized I’m missing a step! What if a and c are equal? In that case, it doesn’t matter what number (a or c) I return, because the max will be equal to both of them.

By the way, I wasn’t totally sure if I’m using the if and elif statements correctly, so I googled “if elif documentation” and verified: “There can be zero or more elif parts, and the else part is optional.”
Cool. But since I’m taking my time, I realize I can make this a little easier to read by deleting the second elif line and replacing it with one character: >=
Now I think I’ve completed my function for when a is greater than b. I’ll do something similar for when b is greater than a:

One of the best parts about Python is the feedback — the error descriptions with an arrow telling you exactly where the error is occurring. If I get an error while running my function, I am that much closer to getting it right. To test my function, I’ll try a few different trios:
Everything looks good until the last two examples. There is no output. I must be missing something since there is no error yet nothing is returned. What am I missing?

In each of the examples with no output, I have a = b. Looking at the code, I remembered to consider when a or b is equal to c, but I forgot the case where a and b are equal to each other! Well, that’s easy enough to add in and test:

Tip: Use print statements at different steps to see what is happening “under the hood” in your function, especially if you can’t figure out where you are going wrong. This is especially helpful for recursive functions, when we get there.

It looks like I have completed writing this function. I am tempted to think, “Big deal — I bet a lot of people could do this more quickly, and I’m not even sure I’m right.” But, I must remember, neither speed nor accuracy were the point of this exercise. The point was to get better at writing functions. And since I had a few areas that I overlooked and went back and fixed them, I succeeded!

Furthermore, I’m never going to use max_of_three because there is a built-in Python function called max that finds the maximum of any number of numbers. But I’m a beginner, and the fastest way to get better at writing functions is not to immediately look at what other people have written but to keep practicing writing functions myself. (FWIW, I’m going to try the rest of these later.) What did I learn in this example? When comparing integers, don’t forget that they can be equal. I did forget on two different occasions while writing it.

Speaking of the max function, it might be a fun challenge to write that function myself! I know the Python function allows for different types of inputs, but if I restrict myself to a list, I bet I could do it.

Fast forward an hour, and I didn’t replicate the maximum function. I’ve gotten to the point where I’m getting errors when I try and translate my thoughts to Python. I’ve taken a few short breaks to get a new take on the problem, but I’ve pretty much stalled out. This is one version I tried:

After this, I tried using the enumerate function. That didn’t solve my problem. I decided to peek at the Python source code, but I realized I didn’t actually know how to do that and couldn’t find it when I tried to look. I did some more searching and found a similar question on Stack Overflow that I don’t fully understand.
So, it seems like I failed. Right?
Remember, the goal was never to replicate the max function. The goal was to learn something by trying to replicate the max function. So, what did I learn?

In short, I tried and failed to replicate something that is built in to Python and I would never have used anyway. However, I learned more by trying and failing than if I had just glossed over everything. Bonus: I had the wherewithal to optimize my time and not waste it by getting in a daze, becoming upset, or taking a long break only to come back and repeat myself. When my progress halted, I “asked for help.”
Do you do anything that I’ve missed in this article? Add a comment if so! I would love to hear from you and to hear about your personal struggles with writing Python functions.
Your home for data science. A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas and codes.
Consultant | Data Nerd | Writer | Fun Person www.miaiseman.wixsite.com/miaiseman
